legacy.full_text:
Google has scanned over 25M books, but you canâ€™t read them.

Fears over cannibalization of print sales & copyright concerns killed much of the project. But it turns out that digitization INCREASED print demand. The effects are big: an average of around $3,750 more sales per book. https://t.co/B8ckuk6aLW

The fact that Gemini Deep Research canâ€™t read Google Books is frustrating. Google is sitting on the largest inaccessible source of knowledge on Earth. 

And if Gemini could find things in Books that were valuable, people would end up buying those useful books, helping authors.

legacy.description:
Professor @Wharton studying AI, innovation & startups. Democratizing education using tech

legacy.full_text:
It is also a way Google could make a big contribution to scholarship. I am not allowed to read the books that I find on Google Book search myself, I have to individually buy them or request them from my university library (if they are available at all).

Maybe Gemini can help.

legacy.full_text: Example: my first peer reviewed paper was on the history of Mooreâ€™s Law. I would love to turn Gemini loose on every issue of the 1960s & 70s Electronics Magazine, which Google Books has but cannot display, to trace the introductions of chips and primary discussions about the Law. https://t.co/Qsh6QbIna6
